item.title: Latest news - Meeting of the DEVE Committee 28 January - Committee on Development
item.description:
The Committee on Development met on 28 January to discuss the following files:

Debates:

  • Exchange of views with Hadja Lahbib, Commissioner for Equality; Preparedness and Crisis Management, and Jozef Síkela, Commissioner for International Partnerships on an integrated EU approach to fragility;
  • Exchange of views with UNHCR, International Humanitarian Relief, Save the Children and DG ECHO on the humanitarian situation in Syria;
  • Exchange of views with WHO on addressing public health emergencies in the Global South: the role of EU aid in enhancing the capacity of national health systems through rapid action to save lives in times of crisis.

Votes:

  • Establishing an EU talent pool: 16 in favor, 5 against, 0 absentions
  • Protocol on the Implementation of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Guinea-Bissau (2024-2029) :
Consent : 18 in favor, 2 against, 1 abstention; Opinion on the PECH non-legislative resolution: 23 in favor, 1 against, 0 absentions.

Draft agenda
Vote results
Video recording - morning debates
Video recording - afternoon debates

item.title: Highlights - Exchange of views on humanitarian situation in Syria - Committee on Development
item.description:
On 28 January from 15.15 to 16.30, DEVE Members will discuss the humanitarian situation in Syria with stakeholders from the UN, NGOs and the European Commission (DG ECHO). The aim of the exchange is to provide Members with a comprehensive assessment of humanitarian needs on the ground, the main challenges to aid delivery and what donors like the EU, and the European Parliament in particular, can do to facilitate it.

Even before the dramatic events at the end of last year, Syria represented the world's largest displacement crisis, with over 13 million people displaced inside Syria and the region. More than 13 years of crisis have driven humanitarian needs inside Syria to record levels amid widespread destruction and economic collapse. The overthrow of the Assad regime in December 2024 displaced an additional 1 million people, adding to the millions of Syrians across the region who require urgent humanitarian assistance.

The speakers include:

  • Mr Gonzalo Vargas Llosa, UNHCR Representative in Syria and UN Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator ad interim for Syria
  • Ms Huda Atassi, co-founder and Regional Director of International Humanitarian Relief
  • Ms Rasha Muhrez, Syria Response Director of Save the Children
  • Mr Maciej Popowski, Director General of DG ECHO, European Commission.

The Chair of the European Parliament Delegation for relations with the Mashreq countries will also address the Committee.


webstreaming

Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP

item.title: Highlights - Exchange with Commissioners Lahbib and Síkela : integrated EU approach to fragility - Committee on Development
item.description:
Following on from the political guidelines set by the Commission President and the commitments made by the Commissioners during their confirmation hearings, the DEVE Committee will hold an exchange of views on 28 January from 10.45 to 12.15 with Commissioners Lahbib (Equality; Preparedness and Crisis Management) and Síkela (International Partnerships) on an integrated EU approach to fragility, which is expected to be proposed by the Commission in 2025.

Commissioners are expected to brief Members on the preparations for the upcoming proposal. Members will engage with the Commissioners on ways to enhance coordination between humanitarian aid, development, and peace efforts to address instability and build resilience in fragile states. This exchange of views will provide an opportunity for Members to offer political guidance on the need for greater European joint action in fragile states and to emphasise the importance of partnerships in view of the upcoming proposal for an integrated approach to fragility.


Webstreaming

Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP

item.title: Highlights - Exchange of views on food and nutrition security in fragile contexts - Committee on Development
item.description:
More than two thirds of people affected by food insecurity live in fragile contexts. On 4 December Members discussed how to address food and nutrition insecurity in these settings in the face of conflicts and the aggravating effects of climate change.

The Development committee held an exchange of views with senior representatives from the World Food Programme (WFP), the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and Action Contre la Faim, which is coordinating the Generation Nutrition coalition.

Next to conflicts and climate shocks, displacement is a particular challenge for food and nutrition security, as people in camps often depend on the distribution of humanitarian aid. At the same time, the EU is committed to better link urgent relief and longer-term solutions.

The speakers discussed how EU aid and development cooperation can contribute to responses in fragile settings. Examples were drawn from the Sahel, Sudan, Afghanistan and other contexts worldwide.


Global Report on Food Crises made by Global Network Against Food Crises
Generation nutrition report - Rethinking the EU’s ODA Investments in Nutrition: Catalyzing Transformative Change,
Video recording

Source : © European Union, 2024 - EP
